author: Deleted User
content: So, after thinking about EIP-3074 a bit more. I now object more strongly than initially. Given that `AUTHCALL` opcode opens up a security hole, and then `AUTH` tries to patch it, a better security analysis is in order (better than me trying to poke holes in it in my free time, which is minimal). My own superficial security analysis gives me conclusion that current version of EIP does trade off convenience of some users for security of most users of smart contracts. If you assume in your threat model that it is possible to occasionally trick a user into a signing a wrong message with its private key, and think about what consequences this has. With current Ethereum, I know that if I am tricked into a signing a message by fishing scam or malware (or in other ways), usually the damage is done straight away and is limited to the effect of 1 transaction (someone steals some of my ETH, or some tokens - usually only 1 type of token). If I am quick enough, I might be able to pre-empt the attack by signing a message with the same nonce. But after the damage is done - that's it. I can keep using my private key safely. With the capabilities of `AUTHCALL` out there, if I am tricked into signing the `0x3 | attacker_padded_address| <any_commit>` , all my tokens and other assets controlled by my private keys are compromised. And I cannot even mitigate it in any way - it is almost like I've given away my private key, only my ETH balance is still safe. You can argue with me, but I do think this is a significant change in security assumptions, and it will apply to all the users once `AUTH_CALL` is activated. What is the alternative? As I suggested before - new transaction type which allows multiple signatures, and `AUTHCALL` being able to select any one them (except perhaps the first one which is `tx.origin`). Multi-sig transactions may be useful for many other things, of course

author: Deleted User

author: lightclient

> Given that AUTHCALL opcode opens up a security hole, and then AUTH tries to patch it
It's really not correct to say that `AUTHCALL` opens a "security hole" and `AUTH` tries to patch it. That's like saying a smart contract wallet opens a security hole and `ecrecover` tries to patch it.

author: lightclient
content:
> If you assume in your threat model that it is possible to occasionally trick a user into a signing a wrong message with its private key, and think about what consequences this has
I don't think this is a valid threat model. If you can trick a user into signing a message, they're at the mercy of how diverse their assets are (if they hold only eth, this can all be transferred out). If we ever support native batched txs then this would no longer be valid anyways since adversaries can trick users into signing a batch the empties out their entire account.

Regardless--let's suppose it is a valid thread model. First, we'll assume the user is using a *sound* invoker contract. In this case, the **worst** that can happen is equivalent to what can happen today. E.g. the adversary is able to get one tx worth of an attack on you and once it is executed the nonce is updated and that's it. You can continue to use your private keys. User should only use vetted invokers and wallets should help enforce that. But we can't *force* it. Just like we can *force* users to store their keys safely or interact with safe contracts. So let's imagine that a user signs a message for an actively malicious invoker. In this case you're right, this is equivalent to given your private key to an adversary. They will have complete control over your account. This can't be done by accident though. The most likely security issue here is that a team builds an invoker that has a small bug. It is very unlikely that bug in the invoker will give full control over a user's account, but it may be able to be exploited to grief the user out of some gas or make some other parameter a little malleable. This is definitely a concern. `AUTHCALL` is like giving users a loaded gun. But the analogy I keep coming back to is that this is exactly like smart contract wallets. Your arguments are equally valid against smart contract wallets as they against `AUTHCALL`.

author: samwilsn
content:
I see three points of contention:
 (1) Should we include EIP-3074 at all?
 (2) Do we break the top-level of execution invariant?
 (3) What do we do with `value`?

The safest option for (2) is to ban self-sponsoring, _for now_. It can always be changed later.

Same for (3). We can require `value` to be set to zero, and kick the decision down the road.

As for (1), there's been nothing here that's new. It's always been very clear in our messaging that invokers have a ton of power. I mention it several times in my Peep an EIP, and it's mentioned in the EIP's security considerations section.
